{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3359543,"name":"Falon Clark","username":"Tatiman-Dev","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tatiman-dev/{size}/236095_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T00:16:05.003Z","cooked":"

I’ve heard that the use of advantagekit for logging and IO layers uses a lot of memory, but I’ve only heard this from one time. I’d like more people’s experiences with AdvantageKit from a memory perspective (Especially if your team uses a Rio 1)

I saw a team having a usb stick connected to roborio1 for logging

We have faced memory problems on the rio 1 but I think it’s due to the large amount of fields we were logging (~300 fields).

AdvantageKit is designed for log replay, and the IO layer it uses for that has costs. If you don’t care about log replay, there’s less costly options for logging. See this recent thread:

AdvantageKit & NetworkTables: Missing Data Programming
I’m sorry that you had this experience. However, the purpose of AdvantageKit is specifically to enable log replay, and not to be a general-purpose logging framework. It it designed with the expectation that NT data will be used exclusively for inputs in subsystem IO interfaces (from vision systems, for example) or for a specifically crafted set of dashboard outputs (which could always be recreated using log replay if necessary). Thus, it does not automatically capture NT data; there is very litt…
","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T04:24:36.444Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":162,"readers_count":161,"score":57.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":462344,"topic_slug":"advantagekit-memory-usage","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/advantagekit-networktables-missing-data/461870/2","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"AdvantageKit & NetworkTables: Missing Data","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/advantagekit-memory-usage/462344/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3359793,"name":"Doug Kavner","username":"dkavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T06:02:56.403Z","cooked":"

We adopted AdvantageKit this year and I don’t know how we ever survived without the logging previously. We did consistently run out of memory for the JRE on our roboRIO-1 until we disabled the NI webserver. We have had no issues since.

Can elaborate what you mean by “better options”? Do you mean manually logging fields with the WPILib logging API?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2024-04-12T08:14:39.644Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":118,"readers_count":117,"score":28.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":462344,"topic_slug":"advantagekit-memory-usage","display_username":"Max Morehead","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":65,"username":"Joe_Ross","name":"Joe Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53784,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/advantagekit-memory-usage/462344/7","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3359810,"name":"Doug Kavner","username":"dkavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-12T08:25:42.000Z","cooked":"

I disagree. AdvantageKit makes it possible to log everything at a low cost compared to the alternatives. And it does it in a way that is compatible with AdvantageScope, which is where the real power lies. We have found that we get better interactive performance by disabling the push of inputs to Network Tables and using the the real-time socket interface instead. This is deprecated, but it still works and I hope they keep it. We still have the full log on the USB stick for later analysis and/or replay.

One option a number of teams used this year was annotation-based logging with Monologue. We hope to bundle it (or something very similar to it) with WPILib next year.
